header.title: Sexism and the English language | The Economist
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: Sexism is rife in language. A woman may be described as bossy, while a man is more likely to be assertive. The Economist's language expert Lane Greene explores the gender stereotypes used in everyday speech. Click here to subscribe to The Economist on YouTube: https://econ.st/2xvTKdy. Daily Watch: mind-stretching short films throughout the working week. For more from Economist Films visit: https://econ.st/2xvTLy8. Check out The Economist's full video catalogue: http://econ.st/20IehQk. Like The Economist on Facebook: https://econ.st/2xvU2RG. Follow The Economist on Twitter: https://econ.st/2xvTMSI. Follow us on Instagram: https://econ.st/2xFoeKe. Follow us on Medium: https://econ.st/2xvTNWM

For all those upset by this video, try this: read some of the comments by women here. I was trying to point out just three things. 1) We often use language in automatic, stereotyped patterns. This is worth questioning in itself. Do you want to write and speak on autopilot? 2) We often use negative language to describe a quality in women where we use a positive word to describe the same quality in men: women who assert themselves in work meetings are far more often called "domineering" or "aggressive" than men are. There is a massive pile of research on this; it isn't controversial. 3) Many "compliments" are not taken as such by the hearer; "feisty" and "articulate" are often taken as condescending. Here is the argument in a column. [LINK] I'm not saying gender differences don't exist. I'm just saying that it's worth thinking about your language and not using it in lazy stereotyped patterns. A bonus to this is that it will make you a more original and arresting speaker or writer.

commentThread.commentText: We need to get that Gender Description Prediction Gap to 0% guys!!

Never in my life have I sat through 3 minutes of such utterly ridiculous and frankly pathetic garbage. Sexism is a very real thing and is happening across the globe as we speak. In some countries women face the kind of prejudice that we in the western world simply fully comprehend. To say that because the word "house" is being associated with women is in any way offensive or discriminatory is the outrageous. And are you suggesting that if we use the word "feisty" as often with men as we do with women that it no longer becomes a problem? I am not sure if you've noticed but there are plenty of words (such as 'macho' or 'heroic') which are more commonly associated with MEN than with women, but yet no one cares, and rightly so. In fact, the 'study' also showed that the word 'killing' is associated with men (and it seems that I should point out to some people out there that being associated with death is more offensive than being associated with housing). However, I understand that that is down to the way in which society has been seen over the course of human history and even has some roots in nature itself. I am not going to kick up a fuss. However, the biggest concern that I have here is the way in which this 'issue' (and I hesitate to call it such) appears to be so prominent in society today. Those students who analysed those books could have spent that time doing something useful or in some way educational. The last time I checked, universities were places of learning and developing a further understanding of the world, not places where people conduct hours of research that proves an ultimately invalid an completely uninteresting point. The west has problems of its own: racism, gun voilence , homophobia to name just a few. For people to spend time conducting such mind-blowingly stupid research while these crimes are happening right outside their doors is an insult to those fighting battles for equality all over the world. How about putting those intelligent young brains to work on improving healthcare, advancing modern science or simply creating a better community for their family and friends. I apologise for my small rant, but I really do think that this kind of rot undermines those who are experiencing ACTU AL sexism. I mean you can imagine the conversation: Person 1: I experie nce sexism regularly. Person 2: Same, what happens to you? replies.commentText: This is more of a psychologically rooted sexism, and the video makes a very valid point. Bat Man thank you for your response. I understand that not everyone shares my view point and that will always be the case. I actually looked into why suicide rates were so high, particularly in young people. It seems to me that there are two main causes of this. Firstly, our culture and idolisation of celebrities sets unrealistic goals for young people to aspire to. Particularly girls feel as though they are somehow unworthy it they don't look like a Vogue cover star. THIS seems to be what lowers young women's self esteem, not the fact that we use different words to describe them, often in situations where would be speaking ill of them in the first place. Secondly, suicide rates in young people are actually higher in boys than in girls. It seems that men have never experienced the same discrimination that women have over the course of history, so this is a surprising fact. Perhaps this is down to the stereotypes of young men/teenagers being reckless and violent. It is worth noting that in secondary school exams, girls always out perform boys and girls' achievements are often celebrated more, possibly to ensure that schools cannot be accused of discriminating against girls. However, this has the opposite effect; making boys feel intelligently inadequate to girls, who are always considered to be the smart ones. Personally, I believe that that these two factors play a far bigger role in suicide rates than using different language to describe a person. As for communism, it's simple: it doesn't work 99% of the time. But that's another matter. My point is that to invest this amount of effort (like the university of Illinois did) and focus so much on one of the smallest and most insignificant 'issues' in the world is a waste. There are plenty of problems in the world, I'm sure that everyone understands that. These larger scale and more damaging forms of discrimination should be the focus of out efforts for a better world. Exactly why we seems to make such a deal out of these kinds of petty problems in the west is confusing, but I think it does have an explanation. As people grow older, (particularly through their teenage years) they feel the need to rebel against something. This is a natural response aimed at making sure that the young leave their parents and create a life of their own; it can be seen in many species. However, in our modern world, we don't have much that our teenagers can rebel against. All of the ills in our lives in the west are on a large scale and are the sort of things that are embedded in our culture and history. Rebelling against these issues could result in upsetting a large number of people. So as a solution, people feel the need to create problems to get angry at. People invent issues like this one and bring them to the forefront of public attention to satisfy a desire to change something in the world. If everyone gets bogged down in things like this, nothing of any real consequence will ever change in the world. Change requires unity. So rather than making a problem to solve, let's all focus on the problems which already exist in the world and see if we can solve some of those. There are too many issues in the world to be creating new ones.

Although I disagree with you, I actually think you make some good points, being the fact that men commit suicide more often than women, and that men are more often associated with the word "kill", which seems quite unfair and sexist. First off, the suicide rate. You're right that men commit suicide more often, but an important caveat is that the rate of completed suicide is higher among men. Women do not differ from men when it comes to attempted suicide, but they are less likely to succeed in doing so. It is not exactly clear why that is the case, but this study is interesting nonetheless: [LINK] As for the reasons for suicide, I agree unreasonable standards are often a main reason for it, resulting in status loss and/or mental illness. I disagree that this is only the case for women. We have made great strides regarding gender, no doubt, but our discourse is still rife with the idea that men should ultimately be ambitious and powerful and so forth. When that is the standard you have to aspire to as a man in order to be 'masculine', it is not strange to see the link with the suicide rate (whether it is in the category 'attempted' or 'completed'). I think the point this video is trying to make is that our language, which often has far more implicit meaning than we give it credit for, has been shaped in a time when life still fit thos e gender roles quite well, i.e. men should be hard-working and successful and women should be caring and pretty. The conundrum we now find ourselves in regardi ng gender seems to be that women are slowly moving into the more traditionally masculine part of gender roles, and are less harmed by masculine expectations but are still harmed by the feminine expectations; men, on the other hand, are not moving into the traditionally feminine very much, which means the unreasonable expectations of traditional masculinity are harming men. We should not discount language as a force for permeating 'traditional' view s on gender. I will grant you that world wide, gender inequality is still very much a different and more concrete problem, but as you point out yourself regarding the suicide rate, it can also reach into the less tangible, more abstract realm of things. The more we progress as a society, the more we will be dealing with those, it seems.

Rokus Loef thank for your reply, as I mentioned it is always interesting to hear what other people have to say when they voice their opinions in a mature way. Perhaps the reason I find this video so utterly mind boggling is because personally, I don't really use different words for different genders (or at least the ones stated in this video). I've never really thought of 'feisty' or 'airhead' as being associated with women. Maybe that's just me. Maybe it's a difficult situation for me to understand because I've never taken a blind bit of notice to how we use these words with different genders and to me personally, it doesn't matter. I find it hard to understand why some people find 'feisty' more offensive 'killing'. While the point you make about language having a more implicit meaning than we give it credit for is definitely true, it is important in a world so filled with hate speech that we learn to grow a slightly thicker skin when it comes to what other people say about us. Not so much so that we end up tolerating racist o r homophobic language (which is never acceptable), but so that we don't let the hidden/implicit meanings of words get to us. The less we begin to feel offended at such small and harmless words, the happier and more self confident we become. There are enough words in the English language to find offensive without thinking up even more.

Andreas Vesalius, I think feisty and killing might actually be equally offensive, or rather, equally harmful. It is not that one is worse, it is that they both entrench and permeate certain views that might not always be good for our society. My personal views, as a male feminist, diverge slightly from the mainstream in that I think the way we use our language and the way we see gender is not exclusively harmful to women, although it is generally more harmful to them as they have historically been marginalised to a far greater extent. I, too, am often unaware of my own biases and stereotypes, but it is nonetheless interesting to try to fight them, in a way. It is strange to see, once you notice it, that boys are more often told not to cry, and girls are more often told not to be 'bitchy', and how these subtle differences in language and norms stratify society along the lines of gender. I also realise I may have treated women less seriously on an intellectual level in the past, and treated men who did not pay for their female date as somehow 'lesser' because they did not fit the role of provider. This is not universal, of course, and some may subconciously hold more biases than others, but the point is that they are often subconcious, and therefore harder to spot. Just as over t racism, embedded in legislation, is often easier to see, but the more subconcious and instincti ve racism is far harder to spot. To be critical of our language does not necessarily mean taking offense. I would be the first to argue that our biases do not necessarily mean we do not intend well. But as our conversation proves, you can both be happy, self-confident and polite within the status quo, yet still be critical of it and aim higher.

Rokus Loef it is certainly true that we do use stereotypes without realising, but my personal belief is that in the context of this video (to do with the language we use) they are of no real effect. I am sure that as a male many people use biased language to me everyday, but I've never really taken any notice and it does not effect me in the slightest. At the end of the day, if someone calls you 'simple', then they are insulting your intelligence. If someone calls you an airhead, they too are insulting your intelligence. One is not more offensive than the other, they both mean the same thing. However this does not apply with killing and feisty. Feisty means to have a notably aggressive or active nature, and I'm pretty sure we all know what killing means and what it's associated with. I am not of the opinion that these are equally as harmful, but the again everyone finds different things to be so. Killing has no positive connotations whatsoever, whereas feisty is often associated with those women who defy stereotypes of being weak and are on a more equal level with their male counterparts. The only context in which feisty is offensive to a woman is if they wish to be seen as weaker or perhaps 'ladylike'. So to sum up, associating someone with killing is to put them on a level of criminals and violence, whereas to associate a woman with being feisty is to acknowledge her strength and her ability to defy the stereotypes which we have held about women for too long.

It is true I took a more childish standpoint to get my view across, but it was not intended that way. I simply reacted to his comment. And from where I stand this issue occurs at times. +Andrew Gisler That's understandable. I'd also be puzzled if I offended someone without meaning to. But that's on me. If I go about my life only abiding by my thresholds of offense, then I'm probably going to bristle a lot of people, and find it hard interacting with others, especially those who look different from me/believe in different things. If you're fine with that, then feel free to live like that. I would just rather get along with others, and if that means I don't call them a certain word, then that's a small price to pay. I wish more people took the time to think about things from another person's point of view, when the other person finds something offensive that you didn't. We can come from vastly different experiences. The easier you're able to understand another person, the more you're equipped to face different challenges. It doesn't cost anything to be nice.

While I understand your point that it is easier to have a positive, happy life by changing yourself to avoid offence, I tend to also think about the opposite point of view. If you're going to go through life being offended by people all the time, even though they have no ill intent, then you're also going to be very unhappy.

It's hard for me to understand why, as a society, we seem to lean more towards blaming well meaning people for their speech than the people that are unreasonably offended when no offence was intended. Given how personal freedom is such a highly sought after ideal, why do we choose the side of repression of speech? Is the "right" to be un-offended more important than free speech?

Now it's great to discuss this as a matter of ideals, but when it comes to real life it's undoubtedly best to adhere, to some degree, to both sides of the argument. Try to be sensitive to others (without tripping over yourself to please everyone) and also try to understand a person's intent before taking offense.

@shimmy.ojeleye

"we police and sanitize our speech all the time."

There's a significant difference between moderating one's language, by oneself, and having a particular group policing and enforcing speech norms, whether by social pressure or legislation.

"there is no government/state made law prohibiting you from offending people"

I'm guessing you're American. On the contrary, you can definitely be sent to jail in for causing offense in probably most countries. Just recently, here in the UK, the Youtuber Count Dankula was charged with transmitting grossly offensive material.

ConsideringPhlebas Can you not keep both ideas in your head at once? The other video was about protecting free speech and being careful not to place limits on it, that, though they may seem noble at first, would undercut one of our most important rights. That's point one. This video was presented in a very neutral, academic tone until the very end when the presenter suggests it would be a good thing to use words in an original manner and perhaps also in a way that does not give unwanted offense. That's the other point. Please explain how that contradicts the notion of free speech. Any authors/speakers watching this video are still fully in charge of the words they use and can take or leave this advice as they choose.

CommaCam

Everyone pays lip service to free speech. As I noted above, speech can be restricted by both government sanction and social pressure. From what I could make of it, the previous video also made the point that free speech should not be restricted by social pressure or government force. I personally do not believe that it is possible to have free expression if the right is given to certain groups to police language and expression and to decide what is acceptable and what isn't. I sensed a difference of tone between the previous video and this one.

ConsideringPhlebas I sensed a difference in tone between the two videos as well: the one about free speech seemed to me like a fairly clear expression of policy/opinion on the part of the Economist; whereas this video was overwhelmingly, save the last line, a simple recitation of academic research into linguistics. My point is that they can both occupy space in the same universe (and in your mind, if you let them) and are in no way incompatible with one another. But what about social pressure to curb speech. Why is that a bad thing in the first place? Should we not care about whether the words we use offend people? Do you not modify your speech depending on your audience, or is it just "all Phlebas all the time," regardless of who you're talking to? You can be polite while still being a steadfast proponent of free speech. Also, someone like yourself, who is clearly adept with language, can surely find any number of different words to make the same exact point. Or you can strategically choose to be offensive -- it's your call. The freedom is still yours. I think one of the things about this video I found so interesting is that some of the words we've used throughout history turn out to have an unconscious association with gender, and might be offensive to people without the author even realizing it. What you (or any other author) chooses to do with that information is up to you.
i once met a feminist who hated blacks and asians. you have to be careful around feminists, they are really just gender fascists.

+ConsideringPhlebas I was wrong about that. Sorry. But In the US we still do have prohibitions on free speech, like "fighting words", obscenity and incitements to violence. These all must pass a fair level of scrutiny. And as you know better than me, speech laws are relatively more strict in European countries. If it were up to me, I'd choose not to prosecute the Youtuber you spoke of. It's obviously offensive, but I think there are better things for authorities to worry about. That being said, he's an entertainer who relies on saying offensive things to get views and instill delight into viewers yearning to hear obnoxious and offensive language they wouldn't dare say in public, or to another person. You know why? Because that's how you lose friends and make people not want to interact with you. I'm sure you can find friends that would be more than happy to partake in Nazi jokes with you, and more power to you guys, but you will most likely also have friends/acquaintances/family who would rather not. And that's fine as well; you would just make sure not to speak like that with them. It's that easy. You respect their opinions/sensibility and hopefully they respect yours. We have always operated by spoken/unspoken rules of conduct and civility. I understand that this is very different from codified laws that hold power to punish you. I also disagree with more vague hate speech laws that can punish speech meant to be comedic. I just think that there are more important issues that one could focus their attention on. The average person isn't going to be sent to prison for tweeting something offensive. Go on Twitter - there are millions of offensive tweets that Twitter just isn't going to bother with. You will most likely be fine. I suspect that Dankula was targeted because many users reported him, due to his large following. Through out history, champions of free speech seemed to be those defending the right to criticize governments. The worst human rights violators around the world continue to police speech as a means to squash any possibility of dissent. It seems that now, in the largely freer and more democratic nations, defenders of free speech only want to protect the right to offend. I agree that offending someone shouldn't warrant government intervention, but the average person isn't going to get locked up for a racist Facebook post. I know I'm not going to change your mind on anything, but it seems that our interests are just widely different. I could think of a dozen other issues that affect millions of more lives and are barriers to progress around the world, but yet people in this comment section are getting worked up because certain words hav e gender specific connotations and usages, that result in people understandably feeling marginalized or stereotyped. You aren't going to get convicted for calling a woman "feisty". This simply isn't an issue. You and I can both agree that Dankula shouldn't be fined, now can you agree that if someone wishes you not call them a certain word, it would be in your best interest to respect their opinion? These are two vastly different issues. And as someone else pointed out, everything except the last line in the video was just a presentation of linguistic facts and observations. Hope you have a good day.
